thread.title_full: Hairopoulos: Oklahoma running back adjusting to life behind new offensive line | Dallas Morning News

author: Kate Hairopoulos
title: Hairopoulos: Oklahoma running back adjusting to life behind new offensive line
text:
NORMAN, Okla. -- Oklahoma running back Samaje Perine in 2014 became the first freshman to lead the Big 12 in rushing, averaging 131.8 yards per game.
But he's being used in a different role this season, Perine pointed out this week.
Four games in, with Saturday's meeting with Texas up next, almost half of Perine's yards have come in the fourth quarter or overtime.
"I'm not taking as many runs early in the game," said Perine, 5-10, 230 pounds, out of Pflugerville Hendrickson. "I'm used as the clock manager when we run to run out some time. ...They know I'm not going to get the same amount of yards as I got last year because of the whole line situation.
"I get yards and our line does a fantastic job at what they can do."
OU is breaking in several new starting offensive linemen and is in its first season in the Air Raid offense. The Sooners rank seventh in the Big 12, averaging 163.5 yards rushing per game. Last year, they led the league with 261.2 rushing yards per game.
OU is averaging 40 rushes per game, compared with 43 last season. Quarterback Baker Mayfield averages 11 rushes per game. Running back Joe Mixon is averaging 34 yards a game.
Perine said the running backs and line have been progressing. He rushed 22 times for 152 yards against Tulsa on Sept. 19, his lone 100-yard game this season. He also caught a touchdown pass in the double overtime win at Tennessee.
"If we're putting points on the board, I'm happy," Perine said. "I don't care about anything else.
"[Defenses] are going to be more focused on the passing game because our running game isn't going as great as we'd like. And once that happens and we keep chugging away at the run game, eventually that's going to pop, and then defenses won't know what to do."
Sizing up Heard: OU defensive coordinator Mike Stoops offered his take on Texas quarterback Jerrod Heard, who will make his fifth start Saturday.
"His ability to create on his feet, elude pass rushers and run the football, that's a great strength of his right now," Stoops said. "He has a strong arm, obviously working on the drop-back game, but he's a very dynamic player, and he's very unique in his ability to be that quick on his feet."
Smooth Seibert: OU's Austin Seibert is the only FBS true freshman who is handling his team's placekicking and punting duties, according to the Sooners.
Out of Belleville, Ill., Seibert is 7 for 7 on field goals and has made all 21 extra-point tries.
Seibert said he took a trip to Dallas this summer and made sure to swing by the Cotton Bowl, the famed site of Saturday's game.
His previous experience with a big-time rivalry?
"Probably Belleville West and Belleville East," he said.
